Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned how to read and analyze Medieval Hebrew poetry, as well as the historical context in Spain and of those poets during that time.
A critical eye toward Hebrew poetry of the Andalusian era. Close reading of medieval texts while supplementing with historical context.

I gained new ways to think about identity construction and cultural navigationAl-Andalus could be here, or there, or everywhere!and I also learned so much about the presence of convention in poetry, the function of irony, alliteration, allusion, and other rhetorical devices, the role of form, the art of translation, Neo-Platonism  the list goes on. By the end of the class, we were all able to have rich conversations about the poetry, a testament to Professor Coles superb teaching ability.
Andalusian history, meter/conventions/style in Hebrew and Arabic poetry

Having no prior knowledge of Hebrew poetry or Medieval Spain, I learned a lot about the poetry, culture, and history of this period. I learned a lot about genres and poetic conventions from the time period and became comfortable analyzing this very complicated poetry.

I learned how to analyze hebrew poetry, and the history of Andalusia that allowed for the development of this poetry. I also learned a lot about Christian, Muslim, and Jewish interactions, and the way that Arab poetic traditions and the Arabic language developed Hebrew poetry and the Hebrew language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The poems and course packet readings were always so engaging and so was the discussion in class.
Wonderful course purely because of Professor Cole and his expertise on the subject of Hebrew Poetry in Andalusia.

Professor Cole is thoughtful with assignmentsI felt like every piece of work I did for this class helped me better understand the material. His feedback was always helpful and kind. I also enjoyed the class discussionseveryone was engaged and passionate about the poetry! Professor Cole, as a person, is the course's main strength. His love for the poetry is infectious, his humility is grounding, and his inquisitiveness is energizing. It is difficult to identify weaknesses.

Professor Cole is an expert and wonderful teacher; any question you have about the material will be answered in great depth. It can feel inaccessible or intimidating at times if you have no background in Hebrew or Judaic studies, but Professor Cole takes time to explain things and the poetry is surprisingly relatable. The class will teach you not to rest on assumptions about the cultural practices of the time.

Strength: Professor Cole is AMAZING and the class is super cool and interesting!! Super niche topic and also great for those who study Arabic/Arab culture!!

Weakness: I wish it was not virtual!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was great!
Professor Cole was generally successful in keeping the class (or at least me) engaged. I think the gentle cold calling was helpful in this regard.
I really liked the virtual discussion pages and presentations that we gave!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!!!!! This class is AMAZING! Professor Cole really cares about his students and he helps you understand the material until the finish line. He is so passionate about his work and you really see it in how he teaches. I definitely became a better poetry reader and writer because of him.

The course builds skills of literary interpretation through a less popular lens and area of study. Even if a student is not a comparative literature major, I'd say this is a fabulous class that one goes to Yale to take.

This class is an opportunity to explore an era of deeply beautiful poetry alongside the man who translated the canon (and whose translations are, themselves, canon). Take it, join the Peter Cole fan club, and never look back.
Yes! Peter Cole is a legendary professor and poet. This course brings you close to his work.
Yes! You will leave this class loving medieval Hebrew poetry, guaranteed.
